description: Borrowed from French chromatique (“chromatic”) or directly from its etymon Latin chrōmaticus, from Ancient Greek χρωματικός (khrōmatikós, “relating to colour; one of the three types of tetrachord in Greek music”), from χρῶμα (khrôma, “colour; pigment; chromatic scale in music; music”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *gʰer- (“to grind; to rub; to stroke; to remove”), perhaps in the sense of the grinding of pigments) + -τῐκός (-tikós, suffix forming adjectives); analysable as chroma +‎ -tic.

adjectives.description: chromatic (not generally comparable, comparative more chromatic, superlative most chromatic)

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Characterized or caused by, or relating to, colour or hue.

examples: Antonyms: achromatic, drab, dull, colourless, nonchromatic

entries.meaning: (not comparable, optics) Having the capacity to separate spectral colours by refraction.
(Ancient Greece, historical) One of three types of tetrachord (the others being the diatonic and enharmonic), with an interval between half and four-fifths of the total interval of a tetrachord.
Relating to or using notes not belonging to the diatonic scale of the key in which a passage of music is written.

description: From chromatin +‎ -ic (suffix meaning ‘of or pertaining to’ forming adjectives from nouns).

entries.meaning: (biology) Relating to chromatin (“a complex of DNA, RNA, and proteins within the cell nucleus out of which chromosomes condense during cell division”).
